Award.AwardTitle: Household Risk Perceptions and Hazard Adjustments to Earthquakes in Oklahoma

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research improves our understanding of the risk perceptions that people have regarding techna hazards (i.e., a natural disaster triggered by technology) with a focus on earthquakes in Oklahoma. Earthquakes are a relatively new phenomenon in Oklahoma, and have become increasingly common since 2008. Residents lack experience dealing with this type of hazard and do not know how to protect themselves or their property in the event of an earthquake. This scientific research contribution thus supports NSF's mission to promote the progress of science and to advance our national welfare. In this case, the benefits will be information for emergency managers to develop plans and campaigns to help residents adjust to earthquakes , taking into account the special needs associated with different demographic groups. The project supports education and promotes diversity through outreach activities aimed at recruiting and retaining under-represented students in research.

This project examines the fundamental understanding of risk in relation to disasters that blur the line between natural and technological. It provides emergency managers with key information they can use to encourage local households to adopt hazard adjustment measures. It builds upon existing hazard adjustment theories and a recent pilot study to address five research objectives: 1) to understand Oklahomans' view of earthquakes, risk perceptions, and levels of adjustment in different earthquake risk zones, 2) to investigate differences in household earthquake hazard adjustment levels across different demographic groups, 3) to understand household views of earthquake triggers (endogenous vs. exogenous), 4) to discover ways researchers can increase their mail survey response rate, and 5) to develop a theory that better describes how households adjust to hazards. By capturing household perceptions of earthquake hazard risks, origins, and implications, along with their understanding of their ability and responsibility to address these threats, this project provides a critical complement to technical assessments of these events.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research enhances our comprehension of people's risk perceptions concerning techna hazards, specifically focusing on earthquakes in Oklahoma—a natural hazard triggered by technology. To provide a basis for comparison, this research project also gathered data on people's risk perceptions and attitudes toward an environmental hazard: tornadoes in Oklahoma. This scientific inquiry contributes to the advancement of science and the improvement of our national welfare. The project's findings are likely to exert an impact on local communities, policymakers, and emergency managers, enabling them to better prepare for and mitigate potential earthquake and tornado risks across the country.

 

Intellectual merit: This study offers insights into how Oklahoma households have been and plan to adapt to the emerging seismic Techna risks, shedding light on the factors that influence their hazard adjustments and hazard adjustment intentions. The enhanced model introduced in this study expands upon the original Protection Motivation Theory (PMT), considering additional factors that shape threat appraisals, coping appraisals, and adjustment intentions. This improved model introduces new variables beyond the original PMT, illustrating how various qualitative characteristics, disaster experience, and hazard salience impact threat appraisal. We also incorporated the concept of usefulness of adjustments for other purposes in coping appraisals, revealing it as a critical variable in explaining adjustment intentions. This enhanced PMT holds promise for future research on different types of hazards, providing a tool to predict adjustment intentions for both natural and technologically-triggered hazards. Additionally, the Extended Parallel Processing Model (EPPM) was used to categorize respondents according to their relative level of perceived threat and efficacy of protective actions in predicting the number of hazard adjustments they intend to or have adopted in response to tornadoes and induced earthquakes. In line with the EPPM, we found that households have the highest number of danger control responses when their perceived threat and efficacy are both high. Contrary to the EPPM literature, we found that low threat coupled with high efficacy moved some individuals toward the adoption of danger control responses in response to both tornadoes and earthquakes. When households have high efficacy, threat appraisals matter in tornado danger control responses but not in earthquake danger control responses. This EPPM categorization opens new research approaches for studies of natural and technological hazards. This study also provides information for local officials and emergency managers making mitigation and preparedness investments and policies. 

 

Broader Impact: the results of this research can guide future earthquake and tornado risk management in Oklahoma and other areas by helping identify and implement actions that encourage precautionary behavior among private actors. Given the unique nature of techna disasters, government entities at all levels in the region should play a leading role in raising awareness about techna earthquake risk. Our research findings can be instrumental in emphasizing adjustment measures that, despite having low adoption intentions, carry a high potential to reduce risk and are relatively inexpensive and easy to install (e.g., securing cabinets). Additionally, governments can address financial barriers for costly adjustment measures such as purchasing earthquake insurance, thereby safeguarding individuals and property from future earthquake hazards. Furthermore, the project's data is currently accessible upon request and will be deposited in an open-source data repository, DesignSafe-CI, within a year after the project concludes. The project findings have been successfully published in five major peer-reviewed journals in the field of risk research. In addition, our research team delivered six conference presentations during the grant period. The materials used for data collection are employed in all the investigators' universities for a range of courses, including Hazard Adjustment Theories and measures, Research Methods, Risk Analysis, etc. Additionally, the project has supported minority and female students pursuing their Masters and Ph.D. degrees.
